heisig_chinese_memo: To avoid INTER-acting with one another, I climbed a tree and kept an eye out for anyone coming near.
heisig_story: The prefix inter- stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: tree . . . eye. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own eye before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for inter-human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: You need to look a tree in the eye to gain a mutual respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: If your respect for the tree is mutual with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's soul (ãã†). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."
WaniKani_Reading_Info: This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.

humanum_full_description_en:
From the " wood " to the " eye ", the image of the characters is visually viewed in the form of wood, which means the meaning of watching. The original meaning is observation, and later it has mutual meaning. "Shuowen": "Phase, look at it. From the eye to the wood." Yi said: "The earth is observable, but the wood is not observable." "The Poem" said: "The mouse has skin in the phase."" Duan Yucai noted "There are many things that the eye sees, but those who look at the wood are not as good as the wood on the ground." It also means that there is mutual meaning. Duan Yucaiâ€™s "Shuowen Jiezi Zhu": "According to the eyes, the objects are called phases. The handover is the xiang. The one who helps the handover is the xiangfeng."

Warring States " with " character " Head Down" or a cross or plus two cross for decoration, see seven states with beryllium. In the ancient seal, the shape next to the " wood " is omitted, and only the " me " and its pen are retained, see "Ancient Seal Collection" 0565. The bamboo slips of the Warring States period are written from the " wood " from the " head ", and the " head " is added with the shape of " also " as decoration. See "Shangbo Bamboo Book IV. "The King of Cambodia Bored Drought" Jane 10.

The "xiang" in oracle bone inscriptions is used as a place name, and the place is in the west of Anyang, Henan. "Collection" 36901: "Wang Bu [Yu] phase."

Bronze writing uses its original meaning to refer to observation. Geng Kettle: "Multiplying together ğ©¡¶ (male)", suspected to refer to the stallion on which it was observed. It also refers to the auxiliary, Zhongshan Wang Fanghu: "Make the virtuous be in the (talent) Liang Zuo Jia, to assist each other (jue) body." Also used as the official name, the word "xiangbang" is often used in bronze inscriptions, that is, the Han Dynasty relative to the country, four years Lu Pu-wei spear: "Lu Pu-state four-year phase-made" Bronze " phase " and read as " mourning ", referring to bereavement, the king seeks to give the bell: "Shun (training) than children and grandchildren, Wan Ye (The world) is dead (without) borders, so donâ€™t use it.

The " phase " of the bamboo slips of the Warring States period means each other. "Zigao" Jane 1: "Goodness and goodness receive each other." It also refers to auxiliary and guidance, "Shangbo Zhushu II. Formerly Jun old "Jane 1:" king of the mother-di (brother) is relative. "And read as" will ", referring to pursue," on Bamboo Slips II. "Parents of the People" Jane 11: "The death (no) body of Feng (li), the sun (just) and the moon phase (jang)." "Book of Rites. "Confucius Leisure Residence" is the "day and month general", the whole sentence refers to the etiquette without a system, every day there is improvement, and every month is followed.
humanum_short_description_en: The word " phase " means observing trees with eyes, the original meaning is observation, and the extension is mutual.

Heisig constituents: inter-, tree, wood, eye
Heisig: The prefix inter- stirs up associations of cooperation among people. From there we read off the elements: tree . . . eye. With only a slight leap of the imagination, those two words call to mind the scriptural proverb about first taking the block of timber out of one's own eye before helping your neighbors with the splinter in theirs. What more useful rule for inter-human relationships, and what more useful tool for remembering this kanji!

Radicals: æœ¨, ç›®  (tree, eye)
Meaning Mnemonic
You need to look a tree in the eye to gain a mutual respect for each other. Stand up straight, look the tree directly in its eye(s). If it looks right back, you know things are mutual.
It's the same with humans, you know? If you want to have a mutual relationship you need to be able to look each other in the eyes. If you're too embarrassed, or you look down on them, then that isn't mutual respect!
Reading Mnemonic
If your respect for the tree is mutual with the respect the tree feels for you, you'll be able to see the tree's soul (ãã†). Right now its soul looks pretty sad, like it's trying to say, "Why are your people cutting down all my friends? I thought we had a mutual understanding."
This is basically a FernGully moment, you know? You can feel the tree's pain like it's your pain. It's that kind of mutual sharing of souls you need.
